http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Stagecraft I is a two-semester course which provides students with both exposure to and experience in all elements of technical theatre, including scenery, props, lighting, sound, costume, and makeup. The four strands emphasize creating, performing/presenting, responding and connecting. In Creating, students generate ideas and original tangible works. In Performing and Presenting, students perform tasks associated with technical theatre and present their work to others. Through Responding, students examine works already created by themselves, their peers, or others to analyze the artistic merit and refine work. Through Connecting, students discover connections between theatrical works and historical, societal, and cultural context. Stagecraft I contains foundational elements of theatre that are not developed in Stagecraft II and III, but the teacher may choose to draw student learning expectations from the Drama II-III Curriculum Framework. Stagecraft II is a two-semester course which allows students to advance their skills in all elements of technical theatre through practical experience, with new instruction in design. Stagecraft III is a two-semester course which allows students to deepen their understanding and advance their skills in specialized elements of technical theatre, which could include scenery, props, lighting, sound, costume, and/or makeup. Stagecraft I fulfills the one-half unit of fine arts credit required for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Stagecraft I, Stagecraft II, or Stagecraft III.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

Generate multiple designs following the steps of the design process
  • analysis
  • research
  • preliminary sketches
  • finalized sketches, renderings or models
  • related paperwork
Collaborate to prepare a design or stagecraft project for a specific drama/theatre work
Utilize a design morgue to enhance design choices
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.
Exhibit leadership abilities in one or more selected technical roles (e.g., designer, producer, technician, stage manager) in the production of a drama/theatre work

Utilize appropriate terminology in regard to stage directions
  • center stage
  • downstage
  • stage left
  • stage right
  • upstage
SLE introduced in Stagecraft I. Refer to appropriate level of Drama for optional extension of SLE.
Refine selected theatrical paperwork

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., résumé, rehearsal schedule, rehearsal report

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Create the documents required to present a design or manage a production

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., ground plans, paint elevations, lighting and sound plots, measurement chart, sketch templates, costume and makeup plots, pull lists

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Refine design choices based on self and peer evaluations
Performing/Presenting
Students will select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.
Interpret a script of literary merit for the purpose of creating a visual/aural design concept
Select design elements to delineate character relationships in a drama/theatre work
Select multiple sources of information (e.g., print resources, web resources, film, video) to inform design choices for a specific drama/theatre work
SLE introduced in Stagecraft I. Refer to appropriate level of Drama for optional extension of SLE.
Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Employ research-based technical elements to increase the impact of multiple presentations
Execute a component of an increasingly complex theatrical design

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., build a set unit, hang/focus light plot, construct a costume piece, style hair or apply makeup

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Refine technical designs or elements as a result of challenges encountered during the rehearsal process
Refine a theatrical design appropriate for a specific type of theatre space

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., proscenium, thrust, arena, black box

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Display proficiency in the design or implementation of scenery and/or properties for a drama/theatre work
Display proficiency in the design or implementation of costumes for a drama/theatre work
Display proficiency in the design or implementation of makeup and/or hair styling in a drama/theatre work
Enforce appropriate safety practices in theatre

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., personal protective equipment, proper use of tools and chemicals, situational awareness, exit procedures

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Defend the rationale for personal artistic choices in a theatrical design which utilizes visual and/or aural elements to convey author's intent
Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.
Analyze dramatic elements of an observed drama/theatre work using more complex theatre terminology
Analyze the contribution of more complex technical elements to the effectiveness of a production
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Compare ways design choices impact mood and meaning of a drama/theatre work
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.
Develop more complex criteria using theatre terminology to evaluate performances, designs, and/or execution of designs
Justify a position taken on the artistic merit of a drama/theatre work
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Synthesize personal experience and technical theatre knowledge to create a design for a drama/theatre work
Evaluate the influence of personal beliefs and biases on drama/theatre work
Evaluate the relevance of various design theories for a drama/theatre work

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., color theory, elements of design, McCandless theory, lighting theory, significant designers

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
Justify artistic choices with regard to societal, cultural, and historical context
Employ design elements and theories to convey cultural and historical context of a drama/theatre work
Employ more complex design elements to convey cultural and historical context of a drama/theatre work
Design one or more technical elements of a formal or informal drama/theatre work that reflects community values and beliefs

Evaluate the effect of cultural perspectives on theatrical conventions/practices (e.g., blackout represents passing of time, set with three walls represents an entire room, soliloquy represents character's internal monologue) in a specific drama/theatre work
Demonstrate cultural sensitivity through appropriate response to the artistic work of others
Plan a formal or informal theatre experience, incorporating arts and media into the design of one or more technical elements
Employ knowledge of theatre history to increase the impact of a theatrical design
Employ knowledge of technological advances in theatre to increase the impact of a theatrical design
